description:
Calvary Mater Newcastle
Temporary Full Time (12 months)
Haematology Trials Department

It is highly recommended that you contact the Trial Unit Manager Michele Gambrill on Tel:02 40144891 to discuss the position and your application

Join one of Australia’s leading health, community and aged care providers
Excellent salary packaging options available
Great career opportunity

About the role

The Clinical Trial Data Manager is responsible for the data entry of specific trials allocated to them as well as assisting in data entry of Trial Office databases when required. The Data manager is expected to:

Manage the data entry as per the study requirements for investigator initiated trials and registries
Coordinate trial and registry requirements in regards to Ethics submissions/annual reports to ensure site is working in line with GCP and National Statement for research.
Support the trial team with general administrative duties
Adopt all new office, site and regulatory processes to ensure effective and efficient quality research
Assist Trial Office staff with data entry of Clinical Trial Management System

What you bring

Qualification in data management or health or science or a combination of qualifications or experience.
Knowledge of medical terminology with the ability to interpret medical record for required information and results
Proven to work proficiently in periods of high demand and activity with minimal supervision.
Proven ability to work independently and as a member of a multidisciplinary team.

Benefits

This is an excellent opportunity to be a part of a leading mission based health care organisation. We offer paid parental leave, salary packaging, career progression, flexible working hours and training and skills development. Calvary is also proud to be recognised as a leader in gender equality. Further details are available here: https://www.calvarycare.org.au/careers/benefits/

About Calvary

Calvary is a national Catholic provider of health, community and aged care services operating in six states and territories. Our services include public and private hospital care, acute and sub-acute care, home care services and retirement and aged care services, in both rural and metropolitan areas. Calvary employs over 11,000 people and has over 1,500 volunteers.

Calvary continues the mission of the Sisters of the Little Company of Mary, a mission focused on caring for those who are sick, dying and in need. We express our values of hospitality, healing, stewardship and respect through “being for others” exemplified by the Spirit of Calvary and the example of Venerable Mary Potter.

How to join the team

To join our diverse, compassionate and dedicated team for a rewarding Calvary career, please submit an online application.

Please note: attached to the job advertisement on the Calvary Careers portal are important documents relating to the role. Please ensure you view these documents before beginning your application. It is suggested that you download a copy of these for your reference.

Candidates must hold Australian or NZ Citizenship or the capacity to permanently work in Australia. Employment of a temporary visa holder may only occur if no suitable permanent resident or citizen of Australia has been identified for this position following suitable labour market testing.

As part of the application process, you may be required to participate in a health evaluation, which could include face to face assessment and drug and alcohol testing, to ensure your suitability for the role.

Please note we are unable to accept emailed applications or resumes and phone calls from recruitment agencies.

Selection Criteria

Essential: Qualification in data management or health or science or a combination of qualifications or experience
Essential: Knowledge of medical terminology with the ability to interpret medical record for required information and results
Essential: Proven to work proficiently in periods of high demand and activity with minimal supervision
Desirable: Proven ability to work independently and as a member of a multidisciplinary team.
Essential: Demonstrated effective interpersonal skills and organisational skills including time management.
Essential: Commitment to the Philosophy of Little Company of Mary Health Care as it applies to the Hospital and the ability and desire to uphold these values.
Essential: Demonstrated effective communication skills both written and verbal

Contact Person

Michele Gambril

Contact Number

(02) 4014 4891

Contact Email

michele.gambril@calvarymater.org.au

Closing Date

29/01/2021
title: Data Manager

description:
The School of Biomedical Sciences

The University of Queensland School of Biomedical Sciences is a distinguished centre for teaching and research in the academic disciplines of Anatomy, Developmental Biology, Physiology, Pharmacology and Pathology. The School has more than 40 full-time research and teaching staff and is one of the largest Schools of its type in Australia. It has links to other prestigious research centres on the St Lucia campus including the Queensland Brain Institute (QBI), the Institute of Molecular Bioscience (IMB) and the Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology (AIBN). Our diverse research provides an exciting environment for national and international research fellows and higher degree students. It is concerned with advancing the understanding of how cellular mechanisms contribute to the function of the human body in health and disease. Details of the research interests of academic staff may be accessed on the school’s web site at https://biomedicalsciences.uq.edu.au/ In addition to its graduate research programs, the School teaches undergraduate students in Science, Medicine, and Health Sciences.

About this opportunity

Reporting to the Curator, the Archives Digitisation Project Assistant is primarily responsible for creating high quality digital records of the Integrated Pathology Learning Centre’s (IPLC) archives using imaging equipment and associated software. The Museum houses one of the most comprehensive collections of pathology specimens in Australia. These specimens are accompanied by hardcopy archival files. The digital archive established will support the long-term preservation of the IPLC paper archive.

Duties and responsibilities include, but are not limited to:

Use a photo scanner to produce high quality digital images of archive records, ensuring that technical specifications and set targets are met
Ensure great care, confidentiality and best practice when handling archival files following the directions of the Curator
Document the digital files to a high standard including standardisation and consistency of data captured

Our Ideal Candidate

We are seeking candidates with an associated qualification including diploma or certificate with post-degree work experience. The appointee will be experienced in digitising archival records or handling archival records/objects and will be highly organised with the ability to exercise initiative and to work to deadlines. In addition, the appointee must be able to demonstrate the following skills and experience:

High level of accuracy, attention to detail and a methodical approach to work
Able to work under general direction to complete tasks, and also work as part of a team
Experienced and skilled in the use of MS Office applications and databases
Experienced in utilising problem-solving skills to diagnose equipment that is not working to standards, escalating where required

What We Can Offer

This is part-time (0.6), fixed term position for one year at HEW level 4. The full-time equivalent base salary will be in the range of $65,424 - $69,453 plus super of up to 17%.

Questions?

To discuss this role please contact Rebecca Lush on email: r.lush@uq.edu.au

For application queries, please contact recruitment@uq.edu.au stating the job number in the subject line.
title: Archives Digitisation Project Assistant

description:
Victoria Police is a large organisation employing police, public servants and protective services officers. Victoria Police provides support to the community 24 hours a day, 365 days of the year. At Victoria Police our goal is for our workforce to reflect the diverse community we serve. We continually seek to attract and retain a diverse workforce which includes people of all genders, ages, religions, disability, sexual orientation, family and caring responsibilities and cultures including people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage.

As a family violence analyst, you will work within the Western Region Division 3 Divisional Intelligence Unit and will be assigned to the Family Violence Investigation Unit. This role provides high level tactical intelligence across the family violence theme. You will be required to analyse statistical data, identify and evaluate emerging trends, provide intelligence support to family violence investigations and produce high quality intelligence products. Your recommendations will be used to influence senior management when tasking and making decisions associated to family violence crime. You will also be responsible for undertaking the collection, evaluation, collation, analysis and controlled dissemination of information linked to family violence.

Victoria Police is a contemporary and agile workplace and support flexible working arrangements

As the successful applicant your duties will include:

Plan and undertake research including interrogation of a range of systems to extract and collate data for analysis.
Build and maintain effective working relationships with key internal and external stakeholders to facilitate information gathering and exchange.
Use of a range of analytical techniques to understand the drivers, causal factors and complexities associated to family violence to inform and assist in the writing of high-quality intelligence products.
Deliver intelligence on key identified current and future risks linked to family violence trends to influence decision making processes.
Maintain and develop a strong knowledge base to drive the intelligence processes.
Support decision makers with high level recommendations by reporting on intelligence analysis in the form of various written products, along with verbal briefings as required.
Maintain intelligence support to investigators attached to the WD3 Family Violence Investigation Unit.

As the successful applicant, you will have:

Sound conceptual, critical thinking and analytical skills
Strong written and oral communication skills
Ability to develop skills to effectively interrogate systems used for information gathering
Ability to respond to changing requirements and priorities, and to adapt to unpredictable circumstances
Tertiary qualifications in the related field of criminology, criminal justice, criminal intelligence science, technology, engineering, or mathematics are highly desirable

Requirements and relevant information:

Ongoing position
Your usual place of employment will be within the Family Violence Investigation Unit in Ballarat. However, you may also be required to work with the Ballarat Divisional Intelligence Unit.
The successful applicant will be required to complete the modules of the Victoria Police approved Intelligence Program relevant to the role as determined by Western Region and qualify within 18 months of enrolment
The successful applicant will be required to undergo National Security Vetting, achieve and maintain a security classification as determined by the Department Head. To achieve this, applicants must be an Australian Citizen.
The successful candidate will be required to undergo pre-employment checks which may include fingerprint checks and misconduct screening.

Your application must include:

Resume
Response to the Key Selection Criteria – found in the position description attached to the job advertisement

Applications close midnight, Monday 1 st February 2021.

Please Note: All applications will need to be submitted through the Job Skills Exchange (JSE) website.
Applications will not be accepted via other platforms or email.

For further information on this role please contact:Acting Sergeant Nicole DAVIES on (03) 53413431 or via email Nicole.davies@police.vic.gov.au .

If you have a disability/medical condition and require a copy of this advertisement and attached documentation in an accessible format or would like to discuss an access requirements/reasonable adjustment for the recruitment process, please contact VPS Recruitment via email VPSRECRUITMENT@police.vic.gov.au or on (03) 8335 8081.

About Us:

Victoria Police is a large organisation employing police, public servants and protective services officers. Victoria Police provides support to the community 24 hours a day, 365 days of the year.

At Victoria Police our goal is for our workforce to reflect the diverse community we serve. We continually seek to attract and retain a diverse workforce which includes people of all genders, ages, religions, disability, sexual orientation, family and caring responsibilities and cultures including people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage.

Find out what it is like working as a Victorian Public Servant for Victoria Police: https://www.police.vic.gov.au/vps
title: Analyst (VPSG3)

description:
Do you have a passion for the environment and enjoy spending time outdoors? As a Project Officer for delivering outcomes under ‘The Living Murray Program’ you will divide your time between the office and the field.

Temporary 2-year contracts with possible extension
Great opportunity to work with the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service

West Branch encompasses 52% of the state and manages 95 parks covering just less than 1.8 million hectares. We are one of eight NPWS operations branches spanning NSW. We are responsible for:

Conserving biodiversity at the landscape, community, species and genetic level.
Conserving landscapes, places or features of cultural, scientific, historic or architectural importance.
Fostering public appreciation of these values.

We do this through managing land reserved under the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974 and protecting those parks’ values. We also undertake other functions in relation to the implementation of the Act and the National Parks and Wildlife Regulation 2009.

About the role

Project Officers will work as part of a small team and will be responsible for monitoring and collecting data on plants, animals, cultural values and their response to environmental watering.

You will be relied upon to use your strong communication and project management skills to develop and deliver projects. You will work with internal and external stakeholders to ensure the smooth delivery of projects, including prioritising works, monitoring and reporting on project budgets, reviewing resource requirements and undertaking procurement.

Essential requirements

Appropriate tertiary qualifications and/or equivalent relevant working experience in project management
Experience in development and delivery of projects, including the development of project plans, monitoring of project timelines, budgets and reporting requirements, and contract administration.

Desirable to have

Current driver’s licence as the role will involve travel
Experience in the field of environmental management and/or ecological sciences including survey.
Experience in managing and analysing large volumes of data
Experience in ArcGIS or spatial mapping systems

Agency overview

At the Department of Planning, Industry and Environment (DPIE) we are focused on creating a liveable, inclusive and sustainable New South Wales with thriving natural environments, strong primary industries and bustling urban centres. We are the stewards of our state’s physical and environmental assets - both natural and built - and we work hard every day to ensure New South Wales continues to flourish.

Our commitment to flexible working

The Department of Planning, Industry & Environment is committed to ensuring the sector reflects the NSW community it serves. We support an inclusive workplace where staff have access to opportunities and resources at all levels, enabling our team members to drive innovation, productivity and delivery of high-quality services. We are open to discussing flexible working arrangements and encourage our people to explore new ways of working - including part-time, job-share or working from different locations. Everyone can ask about it.

Our commitment to Diversity

The Planning, Industry and Environment Cluster strives to be an inclusive workplace for all people. We recognise that we operate in a diverse community and welcome and encourage applications from all ages and genders, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, culturally and linguistically diverse groups, the LGBTIQ+ community, veterans, refugees and people with disabilities.

Junior Research Fellow (Marine Data Science)

Full time, fixed term position for 3 years
Based in Taroona
Assist the Sustainable Marine Resource Collaboration Agreement (SMRCA) Project

The Fisheries and Aquaculture team is part of the Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies dedicated to providing extensive international research, greatly enhanced by key partnership and the development of cutting-edge technology.

The Opportunity

The Junior Research Fellow will work within the Human Dimensions and Modelling program within the Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies (IMAS).

The successful candidate will support research for the sustainable development of fisheries and aquaculture through uncovering, collating, and synthesizing information on marine ecosystems, human activities, and threats in Tasmanian waters.

Key Accountabilities:

Make contribution to the University in achieving its strategic objectives and fulfilling responsibilities.
Undertake high-quality research/scholarly activities.
Contribute to the development and maintenance of productive and effective links.

Your Application

To be successful in the role, your application will need to demonstrate;

A tertiary qualification in a relevant field and/or equivalent qualifications and/or professional experience.
Ability and understanding of research in the field of marine science, environmental science, or geography/spatial science.
Ability in the scientific processing and presenting of spatial data.
A record of contributing to building and maintaining effective and productive networks.

Remuneration

Appointment to this role will be at Academic Level A and will have a total remuneration package of up to $108,076 comprising base salary within the range of $71,443 to $92,373 plus 17% superannuation.

How to Apply:

Please visit http://www.utas.edu.au/jobs/applying2 for our guide to applying and details on the recruitment process.

Applications close Thursday, 4 February 2021, 11.55pm

title: Junior Research Fellow (Marine Data Science)

description:
The Opportunity

Provide IT support at sea on scientific research voyages
Work with state-of-the-art ICT systems and scientific data acquisition and processing software
Join CSIRO - Australia’s premier science & technology research organisation

We are seeking two Software Engineer/Data Analysts to provide support to the Marine National Facility (MNF) research vessel in the areas of software development, data processing, data management and Information and Communications Technology (ICT) network administration.

The MNF research vessel, RV Investigator, has a sophisticated ICT network used to support the operation of the vessel and to collect data from the vessel’s array of scientific instrumentation. In this role, you will spend time both at sea (up to 85 days per year on voyages between 3 to 8 weeks duration), and in our laboratories in Hobart. Whilst at sea, you will be responsible for the running of various data acquisition systems; monitoring the quality of the collected data; administration of the vessel’s ICT network; providing general computing support to voyage participants and liaising with scientists to assist them in achieving the scientific objectives of the voyage. Onshore, your responsibilities will include data processing; maintaining existing software and web interfaces, database services and geospatial tools, as well as developing new software applications and tools associated with the acquisition, processing, visualisation and management of MNF vessel data.

As the successful candidate, you will benefit from on-the-job training and mentoring in CSIRO-specific systems and for the seagoing aspect of the role.

These positions are offered across two levels, with the appointment level being determined by the qualifications, skills and relevant experience you can bring to this role.

Your duties will include:

Developing and maintaining software systems in support of the acquisition, processing, visualisation, serving and management of a wide range of scientific and geospatial data.
Undertaking the role of computing support person on MNF research voyages - operate data acquisition systems, maintain data quality, provide general ICT support to voyage participants and network administration of the information and communications technology on board the vessel.
In conjunction with other electronic and computing support staff, diagnose and rectify hardware, firmware and software problems with scientific data acquisition and instrumentation systems, and with the ship’s ICT network infrastructure.

For appointment at the higher salary level (CSOF4), duties will also include:

Under limited direction:

Proactively identify and take ownership of opportunities for improvements in systems and procedures; analyse underlying issues of complex and ill-defined problems; develop solutions and manage them through to delivery of a positive outcome.
Collaborate effectively with other teams and industry colleagues to achieve objectives.

Location: Hobart, TAS

Salary: AU$63,594 to AU$80,937 pa (pro-rata for part-time) + up to 15.4% superannuation (CSOF3)

or

AU$83,687 to AU$94,679 pa (pro-rata for part-time) + up to 15.4% superannuation (CSOF4)

Tenure: Indefinite

Reference: 71144

To be considered you will need:

A tertiary qualification in Information Technology and/or equivalent relevant experience.
Demonstrated computing skills as follows:

Ability to develop software in modern languages (e.g. Python) and experience with frameworks, libraries and languages relevant to the development of data systems and web-based applications.
Windows/Linux system administration.
An understanding of software engineering methodologies and version control systems.

Excellent interpersonal, oral and written communications skills, including demonstrated ability to clearly document software, data flows and to produce manuals and/or reports.
Demonstrated ability to work collaboratively and interact effectively, sometimes from remote locations, as part of a highly competent and committed team.
A strong customer-centric support ethic with the ability to provide a high level of technical support at sea for the duration of voyages (up to 85 days per year, typically 3 to 8 weeks in duration).

For an appointment at the higher (CSOF4) level, as well as satisfying the Essential Criteria listed above, you must also have:

Demonstrated ability to develop and meet goals, working with clients under limited direction to mutually agreed outcomes and specific deadlines.
Demonstrated ability to proactively identify and take ownership of opportunities for improvements in systems and procedures; analyse underlying issues of complex and ill-defined problems; collaborate with stakeholders outside of the team; develop solutions and manage them through to delivery of a positive outcome under limited direction.

For full details about this role please review the Position Description.

Eligibility

The successful candidate:

Will be asked to obtain and provide evidence of a National Police Check or equivalent. Please note that people with criminal records are not automatically deemed ineligible. Each application will be considered on its merits.
Must be willing and able to work at sea and to travel extensively in order to provide operational support in domestic or foreign ports (up to 85 days per year of seagoing support on voyages that are typically 3 to 8 weeks in duration).
Must obtain an MNF remote medical clearance and a Marine Security Identification Card.

Flexible Working Arrangements

We work flexibly at CSIRO, offering a range of options for how, when and where you work. Talk to us about how this role could be flexible for you. Balance

Diversity and Inclusion

We are working hard to recruit diverse people and ensure that all our people feel supported to do their best work and feel empowered to let their ideas flourish. Diversity and Inclusion Strategy

We are committed to the safety and wellbeing of all children and young people.

About CSIRO

At CSIRO, Australia's national science agency, we solve the greatest challenges through innovative science and technology.

Join us and start creating tomorrow today!

How to Apply

Please apply on-line and provide your CV as well as evidenced-based responses to the criteria, as outlined in the position description.

Applications Close

24th January 2021, 11:00pm AEDT
title: Software Engineer/Data Analyst - Seagoing (2 roles)

description:
Queensland Brain Institute

The Queensland Brain Institute (QBI) is one of the world's leading neuroscience research institutes. Part of the University of Queensland, the Institute is home to over 450 staff and students, which includes 38 Faculty/Group Leaders. Research at QBI spans cellular, molecular, circuit and systems neuroscience. The success of QBI's research is demonstrated by its team of world-leading scientists who publish regularly in the most prestigious international journals.

Clem Jones Centre for Ageing and Dementia Research

This position works within the Clem Jones Centre for Ageing Dementia Research (CJCADR) which was established within the Queensland Brain Institute (QBI) in 2012, focusing on understanding pathogenic mechanisms at a molecular and cellular level and using this insight to develop therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of ageing dementia as well as better diagnostic tools.

About This Opportunity

You will be involved in projects towards the understanding of the role of extracellular vesicles known as exosomes implicated in the spreading and induction of Alzheimer's pathology, using molecular, biochemical and microscopy techniques applied to in vitro and in vivo mouse models. You will have an active role in making and designing experiments, optimisation of techniques, the analysis of data, the critical discussion and presentation of the data, as well as helping in preparing manuscripts.

This position is located at our picturesque St Lucia campus, renowned as one of Australia’s most attractive university campuses, and located just 7km from Brisbane’s city centre.

Our Ideal Candidate

You must have a training equivalent to an undergraduate degree in the area of biomedical science/neuroscience. Demonstrated track records and extensive experience with mouse handling/surgery and manipulation procedures are essential. Experience and expertise in molecular biology and biochemistry techniques, cell culture and microscopy analysis will see you excel in this role.

You will also have excellent organisational and time management skills as well as a high level of written, oral and interpersonal communication skills.

You must have ongoing unrestricted work rights in Australia to apply for this opportunity.

It is a condition of employment for this role that you will be required to provide evidence of immunisation against certain vaccine preventable diseases.

We value diversity and inclusion, and actively encourage applications from those who bring diversity to the University. Our Diversity and Inclusion webpage contains further information if you require additional support. Accessibility requirements and/or adjustments can be directed to recruitment@uq.edu.au.

What We Can Offer

This is a fixed term position until 31st December 2021 at HEW Level 5, with the possibility of renewal subject to funding.

The full-time equivalent base salary will be in the range $70,796 - $78,852 per annum plus super of up to 17%.

The total FTE package will be in the range $82,832 -92,257 per annum.

You will be able to take advantage of UQ Sport Facilities, recreation leave loading (of 17.5%), salary sacrificing options, on-campus childcare, discounted private health insurance, affordable parking, development programs and many other benefits.

For further information, please review The University of Queensland's Enterprise Bargaining Agreement 2018-2021.

Questions?

To discuss this role please contact Dr Juan Carlos Polanco j.polanco@uq.edu.au or Professor Jürgen Götz j.goetz@uq.edu.au.
title: Research Assistant

description:
Industry placements with leading industry partners
Development of thermal spray coatings onto novel substrates
$34,013 p.a. for up to 3.5 years (full-time, fixed term)

About the Centre
Swinburne’s ARC Training Centre in Surface Engineering for Advanced Materials (SEAM), led by Swinburne Distinguished Professor Chris Berndt, with 18 Chief Investigators, will be the first ARC funded training Centre of its kind in Australia, delivering commercial benefits for industry. The Centre will integrate industry-university cooperation for applied training within an industrial setting, cover a spectrum of important research themes and applications including biomaterials, graphene layering, high temperature coatings, laser metal deposition for materials repair and Industry 4.0 manufacturing processes, and aspires to provide pathways for job creation and a high-quality workforce in manufacturing. Further information on SEAM can be found at www.arcseam.com.au
About this Scholarship(s)
SEAM is looking for candidates who will work on a specific project on the development of thermal spray coatings onto novel substrates. The candidates will be closely integrated with key industry partners, located in Melbourne, Australia.
Eligibility Criteria

Essential: Strong metallurgy and materials science background;
Highly desirable: Experience in surface engineering, especially thermal spray coatings;
Desirable: Experience in understanding and managing wear and corrosion processes;
Desirable: Experience in using composite materials.

To be eligible for this scholarship you need to have:

First-class or 2A honours, or a Masters by research in engineering/science;
Analytical thinking, data analysis and critical problem-solving skills;
Excellent time management skills and ability to work independently
Ability to work as part of a multi-disciplinary research team;
Evidence of good oral and written communication skills;
Applicants with publications will be highly regarded.
Must meet Swinburne’s entry requirements for the Doctor of Philosophy;
Australian citizen or Australian permanent resident, or ability to self-obtain an Australian visa.
Must be in a position to enrol and commence the PhD candidature by July 2020.

Close date
Applications will close when the successful candidate has been appointed.

Start date
Local applicants are encouraged to apply, envisaging an immediate start date, pending satisfactory entry criteria.

Enquiries
All scholarship specific queries can be directed to SEAM Business and Operations Manager via (03) 9214 3497 or seam@swin.edu.au

Terms and conditions
The scholarship will be governed by the Swinburne Research Scholarship Terms and Conditions. https://www.swinburne.edu.au/research/research-degrees/degrees-programs/phd-doctor-of-philosophy/

All appointments are subject to a valid Working with Children’s Check, therefore it will be a mandatory requirement to have and maintain a current Working with Children Check.

If you require support due to special needs or alternate considerations, please contact our Diversity Consultant, Dr. Walter Robles, on inclusion@swin.edu.au. For support or queries related to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander employment, please contact DeadlyCareers@swin.edu.au.

How to apply
Start your application by clicking the "begin" button to upload a resume, cover letter and a copy of your academic transcript.

Applications close when the successful candidate has been chosen.
title: PhD Scholarship in Corrosion

description:
Sydney Children's Hospitals Network is the largest paediatric health care entity in Australia. We care for thousands of children each year in our hospitals and in their homes — with one purpose in mind — to help young people live their healthiest lives.

Employment Type: Temporary Part Time up to 01-Feb-2022
Position Classification: Admin Off Lvl 6
Remuneration: 70635.7 - 72384.72 (full time equivalent)
Hours Per Week: 19
Requisition ID: REQ205281
Location: Westmead
What you'll be doing

Background

The incumbent will work as part of a small research team headed by a clinician researcher within a department with an established research track record over many years.
The research team’s focus is on the development and utility of novel lung function tests (Multiple breath washout and Forced Oscillation technique) that may improve early detection and subsequent monitoring within important respiratory conditions. These novel tests can be used across all ages, including within the infant and preschool age range. The role will involve expertise in these tests.
This role offers opportunity to develop skills in a variety of lung function techniques under supervision.

Role

Undertake research activities as part of a team.
Produce and/or contribute high quality data for conference presentations, manuscripts and funding applications. Mechanisms exist within the research team to fund travel to conferences to present the data if the contribution warrants it.
Help with the supervision or guidance of more junior research personnel working within the team across existing projects.

Research activity and directions

Undertake research studies according to the approved study protocol, including:
Recruit and screen patients ensuring enrolment targets are met
Schedule attendance by children for study visits ensuring adherence to study protocols
Conduct physiological tests, including novel tests such as multiple breath washout and forced oscillation technique, and relevant quality control procedures
Enter data, manage paperwork, databases and spreadsheets
Contribute to data analysis to provide summary statistics
Expertise and advanced interpretation of data will be developed within this role.
Assist in the design of protocols and analyse plans as required for specific studies.
Contribution to the development of new research ideas/proposals collaboration with the team

Lung function testing

skills will be developed under supervision to perform lung function tests in specific patient groups, such as cystic fibrosis.
The ability to perform these tests in younger age groups will be developed in the role.

Technical skills

Become competent in a range of techniques relevant to the broad field of work within the Department of Respiratory Medicine
Able to work independently
Able to provide back up support for staff and students whose projects involve similar tests
Develop technical expertise within the research group.

Bachelor of Science, Bachelor of Nursing degree or equivalent

Computer literacy – including statistical analysis programs (e.g. SPSS or equivalent), and microsoft word including excel and powerpoint (or equivalents).

Experience in the conduct of a research project for example application for ethical review, data collection and manuscript submission.

Effective oral and written communications skills

Experience of data entry into databases and in data analysis and use of statistical packages such as SPSS

SCHN is an Equal Opportunity Employer and encourage all suitably qualified applicants to apply, including Indigenous Australians, and people from culturally diverse backgrounds.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are encouraged to apply. We recognise the value of Aboriginal staff providing health care to Aboriginal children and families that access the services we provide at the Sydney Children’s Hospitals Network. Aboriginal job applicants are encouraged to visit the NSW Health Aboriginal Recruitment tool, Stepping Up to assist in preparing your application.

Need more information?
2) Find out more about applying for this position
For role related queries or questions contact Paul Robinson on paul.robinson1@health.nsw.gov.au
Applications Close: 31/01/2021
title: Research Assistant

description:
Title:

Ecologist

Advertiser:

Conservation Ecology Centre

Location:

Apollo Bay, Victoria

Salary etc:

$63,350 p.a. + super

The Conservation Ecology Centre is a scientific organisation generating knowledge to nurture Country. We combine rigorous research with practical land management and work with our community to restore habitats, build knowledge and develop and deliver solutions to the most urgent conservation challenges in the Otway region. We partner with public and private land managers, NGOs, traditional owners, research institutions, government and community to bring about real change in flora and fauna conservation.

The organisation was founded in 2000 alongside the Great Otway National Park. DGR status was granted in 2006 as Conservation Ecology Centre projects and programs developed across the region. Alongside conservation research programs, the organisation has also developed an integrated social enterprise model, operating the Great Ocean Ecolodge since 2004 and developing the new Wildlife Wonders project which is scheduled to open early 2021. These social enterprises contribute to financial sustainability and provide outstanding community engagement.

Key responsibilities and accountabilities:

The Ecologist will work in collaboration with the CEC team in the following activities:

Research & Project Management

Assist CEC team to develop a new research theme exploring the role of fire in the Heathlands of the Otway Range.
Design research projects to answer specific knowledge gaps pertaining to planned fire in the Otway Range.
Ensure projects have adequate permit arrangements and organise the field logistics of research projects, including equipment and resource management.
Lead and monitor data collection in the field and ensure quality of data.
Supervise volunteers, students and interns and train and assist in field research techniques.
Ensure good communication and team relations between CEC staff, volunteers and external stakeholders.
Assist in the development of research projects, analysis of data and written communication of research when required.
Contribute to project funding plans and budget management.
Undertake work on a variety of research projects in the fields of conservation ecology, threatened species recovery and, habitat restoration as required.

Other responsibilities and accountabilities

Collaborate with CEC staff to create regular news and stories for the website, social media and newsletters.
Comply with and uphold CEC's OH&S policies and procedures.
Participate in meetings and presentations where requested.
Any other tasks the Conservation and Research Manager deems necessary within the broad remit of this role.

Key Selection Criteria:

Relevant tertiary qualification in an environmental or related discipline (eg. conservation, ecology, environmental science, biology, wildlife ecology).
Honours, Masters or PhD in an environmental or related discipline (Preferred).
Demonstrated experience in Conservation Research, including project design and management, collection/collation of data and interpretation and high-level analytical skills with a preference for experience in Fire Ecology, Wildlife Ecology, Disturbance Ecology or Botany.
Demonstrated experience working in remote field conditions.
Experience and/or training in 4WD, 4WD recovery, First Aid and Crosscut (Preferred).
The ability to take a strategic and practical/common sense approach to the delivery of projects.
The ability to form and maintain strong relationships with internal and external stakeholders.
Excellent written and spoken English communication skills and the ability to effectively and concisely communicate complex issues.
Passion for conservation and an alignment to the CEC's organisational values.
Sound knowledge of South-eastern Australia's biota and ecosystems.
High levels of initiative with the ability to successfully achieve objectives.

Note: This position does not involve a responsibility to independently lead research or personally create material for publication without endorsement by CEC Executive and Board.
title: Ecologist

description:
Salary Package: From $73,922 to $84,047 p.a. pro-rata (HEW Level 5) plus 13.25% employer's superannuation and annual leave loading.
Appointment Type: 12 months, part-time, 21 hours per week
Location: Macquarie University (North Ryde)

The Role

We are seeking a Research Assistant with a proven track record in clinical research to provide research support to the lead investigators of the Back Complaints in the Elderly: Chiropractic – Australia (BACE:C-A) study. This project will provide important insights into primary care management of older people with back pain in Australia. The successful applicant will coordinate and assist with the collection of practice-based data through online survey platforms, which includes direct communication with primary care clinicians and their patients. The BACE:C-A is a 12 month longitudinal study that will follow the clinical course of back pain in 300 older adults, and therefore the successful applicant will assist in the management of this very large database, and will be able to perform and interpret statistical analyses. The successful applicant will also be able to synthesise and prepare data for reports, presentations and publications.

Key responsibilities include:

Coordinate a clinical, practice-based research project
Manage the collection of longitudinal, practice-based data captured via online survey platforms
Perform and interpret the statistical analysis of large datasets
Work independently and as part of a team, while being able to meet tight deadlines and adapt workloads as necessary.

About You

You will have knowledge gained from a relevant degree in public health or health science and have previous clinical research experience, ideally within the university sector. You will have experience in the management of large datasets, and in particular be able to perform and interpret statistical analyses relevant to longitudinal studies. You will be proficient in the coordination and implementation of policies and procedures related to clinical research. You will demonstrate a strong attention to detail and be able to work with local and international research partners. You will be an excellent communicator with healthcare clinicians in the field, have strong interpersonal skills, and you will thrive off working in a team and collaborating with a range of stakeholders.

MS Office computer skills, demonstrated experience with statistical software such as STATA and SPSS, and expertise in using online survey platforms (Qualtrics and REDCap) and research software (such as EndNote and NVivo) will set you up to succeed in this role.

About Us

Macquarie University's Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences builds on our aspiration to have the nation's first fully integrated Academic Health Sciences Centre under a university's leadership. It brings together the excellent work of medical and allied-health clinicians and researchers across the University and around the country, with unparalleled access to the world-leading clinical resources and research facilities found only on our campus.

The Department of Chiropractic delivers Australia’s oldest University based Chiropractic degree, preparing work ready chiropractors with an evidence-based view to address and prevent disorders of the musculoskeletal system.

Macquarie is a university engaged with the real and often complex problems and opportunities that define our lives. Since our foundation 54 years ago, we have aspired to be a different type of university. Over the years, we’ve grown to become the centre of a vibrant local and global community. Connect with us today.

To Apply

To be considered for this position, applicants will need to respond to the below selection criteria in their CV and a 1-2 page cover letter:

Essential criteria:

A tertiary degree in a relevant discipline including public health, health science, or health services research
Demonstrated experience coordinating a clinical research project, preferably in the university sector
Demonstrated experience using online survey platforms (Qualtrics and REDCap) and managing large databases
Experience using the statistical software program STATA, as well as performing and interpreting descriptive and inferential statistical analyses
Excellent research organisational and time management skills, including meeting competing deadlines

For further information regarding this role please view the position description here: Research Assistant_HEW 5_Dec 2020_PD.pdf

Given current Australian Government COVID-19 border restrictions applications for this position are only being accepted from Australian citizens or permanent residents or people currently residing in Australia with full working rights.

Note: This position requires a criminal record check

Role Enquiries: Dr Katie de Luca, Post-Doctoral Research Fellow via e-mail katie.deluca@mq.edu.au

Applications Close: Tuesday 26 January 2021 at 11:55pm (AEDT)

Macquarie University is committed to Equity, Diversity and Inclusion. We value individual difference and recognise the strength of a vibrant, diverse and inclusive workforce where the backgrounds, perspectives and experiences of our staff are a driving force for collaboration, innovation and impact.

We work to ensure genuine equality of opportunity for people regardless of their gender, age, cultural background, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability and/or family status, and we encourage you to apply for a position at Macquarie University.
title: Research Assistant

description:
Job Description

Location: Melbourne | Northern Metropolitan

Job type: Not provided

Organisation: Melbourne Health

Salary: Salary not specified

Occupation: IT and Telecommunications, Research

Reference: 54940

Software Engineer required to design, develop, test and maintain software applications for the medical research sector
Join a leading data organisation, BioGrid Australia, to support its virtual data platform with provision of technical solutions for clinical and research datasets
Salary packaging options and flexible working arrangements

The Royal Melbourne Hospital

As one of the largest health services in Victoria, and a team of more than 10,000 strong, we provide a comprehensive range of specialist medical, surgical, and mental health services; as well as rehabilitation, aged care, outpatient and community programs. We are a designated state-wide provider for services including trauma, and we lead centres of excellence for tertiary services in several key specialties including neurosciences, nephrology, oncology, cardiology and virtual health.

Surrounded by a Parkville Precinct of brilliant thinkers, we collaborate to set new benchmarks in health excellence – benchmarks that impact across the globe. While the work we do takes us in inspiring new directions; caring for each other, our patients and consumers is as essential to who we are, as any scientific breakthrough we make. We put people first - leading with kindness and working together, we excel as one Royal Melbourne Hospital.

Your Opportunity

BioGrid is looking for a passionate and dedicated individual to join the Project and Data Services team at BioGrid Australia. This is a Full Time Fixed Term position with the intention of renewal of contract at the end of the fixed term for a successful candidate. Your success in this role will be in your ability to:

Design, develop, test and maintain software applications and databases using modern software development methodologies.
Prepare relevant documentation including installation guides and kits for software applications being developed.
Control scope of the development and identify and facilitate resolution of deviations from the project plan in consultation with Data and Business teams.
Deploy and/or support the deployment of software applications at various hospital and client sites as required.
Assist with development and review of software development and business processes utilising JIRA, Confluence and written Policies and Procedures.

About You

Degree in Computer Science or Information Systems (or equivalent).
Experience in a health/biomedical science environment is highly regarded.
Experience in a range of software development technologies such as:

Object Oriented Programming: C#, C/C++, Java, Visual Basic;
Web Development Technologies: ASP.NET, ASP.NET Core, Angular NHibernate, HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, JavaScript, JQuery; Angular JS, ASP.net MVC, Entity Framework

Demonstrated high level interpersonal skills (verbal and written).
Ability to meet tight deadlines and to work efficiently and effectively.
Ability to work autonomously under minimal supervision, and in a team environment.
Excellent organisational, time management and prioritising skills with ability to manage multiple conflicting priorities under pressure.
Excellent problem solving and problem management skills with a strong desire to 'do it right' the first time.
Self-motivated and directed, with keen attention to detail.

Our Commitment to you

Here at The RMH we strive for excellence with a strong purpose that defines the work we do for our community – Advancing health for everyone, every day. This is the Melbourne Way.

We believe our success comes from our people. We’re committed to the RMH being a great place to work and a great place to receive care. We have made a long-term commitment to strengthen our organisational culture through leadership, education and empowering our staff to Speak Up for themselves and each other.

The RMH stands in solidarity with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in work and care. We are proud to be a workplace that champions diversity, inclusion and equality for our staff and our community. Our goal is for our people to feel safe, included and supported so that they can be at their best every single day. We encourage talented people from all backgrounds, abilities and identities to apply to our vacancies, and will consider adjustments to support such applications.

Interested?

Find out more about BioGrid Australia https://www.biogrid.org.au/ and The Royal Melbourne Hospital https://www.thermh.org.au. If you have any questions or require more information, connect with us. We look forward to hearing from you.

All appointments are made subject to a satisfactory Criminal History Record Check and a Working With Children Check. Successful applicants will be required to provide evidence of an immunisation assessment prior to commencement.

For a confidential discussion please connect via the details below.

Javier Haurat, Project and Data Services Manager, BioGrid on 03 9342 2690.
title: Software Engineer

description:
GeoGAS is currently seeking a flexible, enthusiastic and motivated person to join the team as a Laboratory Technician on a full-time basis.

As a Laboratory Technician within the Mackay laboratory, this role will be responsible for the preparation and testing of coal samples. The prime responsibility of this role is to perform and maintain the required quality standards during the daily operational activities of the testing laboratory using safe and productive work methods.

ABOUT THE ROLE

Responsibilities include:

Test coal samples and carry out testing procedures to GeoGAS standards.
Dispatch and Receipt activities and may include organising equipment for client projects including.

gas content testing;
coal quality testing, eg proximate analysis and relative density;
data entry;
laboratory maintenance & calibrations; and
general housekeeping.

Complete maintenance and calibrations procedures and schedules.
Assist in the day to day operations of the laboratory.
Organize and manage time effectively and prioritize sample testing.
Take part in non-core activities as directed.
Compliant with laboratory safety procedures and OH&S standards.
Ensure that all safety schedules and standards are completed.

ABOUT YOU

Skills and experience required include:

A commitment to promoting laboratory safety, including good housekeeping practices.
Candidates must be fit to perform physical duties. Role requires repetitive manual labour, including lifting 10-15kg objects on a daily basis. Candidates may be required to undergo a pre-employment medical assessment.
Previous laboratory experience in a coal testing environment.
Tertiary qualifications in Geology or Environmental Sciences.
Familiarity with NATA, Australian Standards and ISO 17025.
Demonstrated proficiency in Microsoft Office Suite.
Good communication skills.
Work well as part of a diverse team
Enthusiasm to make a positive contribution to the team environment.
The ability to follow instructions, pay close attention to detail and take precise readings.
Demonstrated numerical skills required to check test results and perform simple calculations.
The ability to work methodically, quickly and accurately maintain records.
The ability to multi-task and flexibility to adapt to changing work practices.
Excellent organisational skills and problem solving skills.
A strong work ethic and commitment to producing quality work.
Available to work during school holiday periods.

Salary range: AUD53,000 - 63,000 (excluding superannuation)

ABOUT GEOGAS

GeoGAS, a part of RPMGlobal, provides laboratory and consulting services to the mining and CSG industries.

GeoGAS has over 20 years’ experience in consulting and laboratory testing and one of the most comprehensive gas reservoir databases in Australia. Our experience and capabilities cover underground mine gas management through to coal bed methane gas production.

Our testing and consulting services help our customers to manage gas released during the mining process, define the nature and value of their coal and gas resources, prepare CSG statements for lease applications and comply with environmental legislation on carbon and greenhouse gas emissions.

GeoGAS’s mission and goals are underpinned by core values which are embedded in everything we do. Positive work behaviours aligned with our core values enable us to be an effective, productive and competitive business.

GeoGAS fosters a work/life balance approach to the workforce and recognises the skills and abilities of all staff by encouraging promotion from within.
title: Laboratory Technician

description:
Employment Type: Permanent Part Time
Position Classification: Administration Officer Level 2
Remuneration: $28.05 - $29.04 per hour plus superannuation
Hours Per Week: 16
Requisition ID: REQ208035
Location: John Hunter Hospital
Applications Close: 1 February 2021 - 11:59pm
About the opportunity
Being part of NSW Health Pathology means you’re helping create better health and justice systems every day.
We operate more than 60 laboratories and around 200 collection centres across NSW and conduct over 60 million tests per annum. Our network of pathologists are supported by scientists, technicians and support staff who quickly and accurately assess samples so clinical teams can make the best possible treatment decisions for patients. Our Forensic & Analytical Science Service provides independent, objective analysis to the NSW criminal and coronial justice systems.

What we can offer you

Generous salary packaging options and other fringe benefits
Corporate wellbeing programs, including the Fitness Passport
Learning and development opportunities, including in-house training with RTO My Health Learning

What you'll be doing
The Administration Officer is responsible for the efficient and effective provision of administrative services within the Pre-Analytical, Data Entry Department.
The Administration Officer is required to provide competent computer skills to support the effective and efficient functioning of the Pre-Analytical, Data Entry Department.

Interested in joining Australia’s largest public pathology service? Apply now by addressing the following questions:

Suitable communication and interpersonal skills with ability to work effectively as part of a team and to liaise confidently and courteously with people at all levels.
Ability to undertake various administrative tasks and perform duties with attention to detail.
Competent skills in computer use and relevant software programs eg Word, Excel, Outlook.
Experience in providing administrative support within a healthcare or similar setting.
Capable organisational skills with proven ability to determine work priorities and meet deadlines.
Experience in Data Entry/Administration in a Pathology setting.

Need more information?
2) Find out more about applying for this position
For role related queries or questions contact Carmen Cleare on Carmen.Cleare@health.nsw.gov.au

Occupational Assessment, Screening and Vaccination Against Specified Infectious Diseases
This is a Category A position. All Category A applicants must read and understand NSW Health Policy Directive PD2020_017 Occupational Assessment, Screening and Vaccination Against Specified Diseases. All new recruits must agree to comply with the requirements outlined in this policy. New recruits must provide evidence against specified diseases and comply with the requirements of this policy at their own cost prior to appointment.
Working Rights
This position is a permanent position. To be eligible for permanent appointment to a position in NSW Health, you must have an Australian citizenship or permanent Australian residency. Please note: A person who is not an Australian citizen or a permanent resident is only eligible for temporary employment for a period not longer than the duration of their current visa.

New to NSW Health Pathology?
he preferred candidate may be required to undergo a functional assessment prior to appointment.

Talent Pool
If the selection panel identifies more than one suitable candidate for the role, an eligibility list will be created for future permanent part time, temporary and casual vacancies.
title: Administration Officer

description:
Job no: 495227
Work type: Full time
Location: Hobart
Categories: Administration, Information Technology, Laboratory & Research Support

Software Engineer

Full time, fixed-term position for 12 months
Based in Hobart

The Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS) is part of the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Research) Division, and is a national collaborative research infrastructure, supported by the Australian Government.

IMOS is designed to be a full-integrated, national system, observing at ocean-basin and regional scales, and covering physical, chemical and biological variables.

The Opportunity

IMOS is seeking to appoint a skilled Software Engineer with a background in computer science, database administration and data management.
The successful candidate will work within the Australian Ocean Data Network (AODN) facility, responsible for assisting in the design and implementation of new data management systems to support data collection activities of IMOS facilities.

All observations collected by IMOS facilities and associated data products are discoverable, accessible, usable and reusable via the Australian Ocean Data Network (AODN). Increasingly, even more data is being made available via AODN from a wide range of partner organisations – research institutions, Federal and State Government departments, and private industry.

Key Accountabilities:

Implement new web-based data management systems.
Work with internal and external stakeholders to perform systems analysis tasks.
Develop systems in line with defined architectures and established organisational practices.
Work with other members of IMOS/AODN on system design, delivery, transition, and maintenance.
Document completed work including code, develop manuals for the use of systems and document processes and procedures where appropriate.

Your Application

To be successful in the role, your application will need to demonstrate;

Tertiary qualification in Computer Science (or similar) with relevant experience or equivalent extensive experience.
Significant experience developing and maintaining REST API’s and database persistence mechanisms using Java (preferably using Spring).
Experience with open source geospatial applications.
Experience with cloud computing environments.
Background knowledge in database design and implementation preferably using PostgreSQL and PostGIS..
A methodical approach to development and documentation of software and systems.

Remuneration

Appointment to this role will be at HEO 7 and will have a total remuneration package of up to $105,219 comprising base salary within the range of $87,423 to $96,090 plus 9.5% superannuation.

How to Apply:

To apply online, please provide your resume, cover letter outlining your suitability and motivation for the role, and your responses to the position/selection criteria.
For further information about this position, please contact Cameron Moloney, Information Infrastructure Team Leader – AODN, Cameron.moloney@utas.edu.au or 03 6226 8586.
Please visit http://www.utas.edu.au/jobs/applying2 for our guide to applying and details on the recruitment process.

Applications close Sunday, 31 January 2021, 11.55pm

To be eligible for this position, you are required to have Australian citizenship, permanent residence or a current valid visa that allows you to fulfill the requirements of this role.

Advertised: 13 Jan 2021 Tasmania Daylight Time
Applications close: 31 Jan 2021 Tasmania Daylight Time
title: Software Engineer

description:
Research Officer

Make an important contribution to the health of children through medical

research

Work with one of Australia’s most respected national and independent

medical research institutes

Located in Westmead, one of Sydney’s and Australia’s major biomedical

research hubs

Salary Range ($88,000 - $95,000) + Super + benefits

Children’s Medical Research Institute (CMRI) was Australia’s first dedicated paediatric
research facility and is now one of the world’s most highly regarded independent medical
research centres. Our research focuses on the areas of embryonic development and birth
defects, cancer, neuroscience and gene therapy and we have a strong international
reputation based on our research outcomes. It is also home to the world-first proteomics
project, ProCan, which is changing the way cancer is diagnosed and treated. CMRI’s
research programs are supported by state of the art facilities and committed research and
support staff. Our achievements are made possible by a loyal network of community
supporters, highly engaged donors and the very successful Jeans for Genes® fundraising
campaign.
Applications are invited for the position of Research Officer in the Molecular Neurobiology
Research Group (MNB) led by Dr Gold and Translational Vectorology Unit (TVU) led by
A/Prof. Lisowski. Up to 4 positions are available. The TVU is located in the CMRI and
specialises in the development of novel recombinant adeno-associated viral vectors
(rAAV) and individualised gene therapeutics for the treatment of rare paediatric genetic
conditions. The MNB group is located in the Westmead precinct with research activities
being conducted at the CMRI and at Kids Research (The Children’s Hospital at
Westmead) and specialises in rare paediatric genetic disorders of the CNS.
The successful applicants will be responsible for working independently and as part of
larger research group and perform research in the area of translational molecular biology
under PC2 conditions. The candidates will be expected to:

Undertake research activities with limited day-to-day supervision, as part of a

team.

Develop technical expertise within the research group.
Produce and/or contribute to high-quality research data for conference

presentations, manuscripts, funding applications.

Contribute to and/or be responsible for administrative duties associated with

research, the work of the organisational unit, and/or the department or institution.

Contribute to written preparation of manuscripts or funding applications.
Supervise junior staff and students and take responsibility for the day-to-day

operation of a work unit.

Be responsible for performing a wide range of molecular biology assays including,

but not limited to, molecular cloning, DNA/RNA purification, qPCR, blotting and
sequencing.

Be directly involved in culturing and manipulating patient cells, designing, cloning

and applying currently available gene therapy and gene editing tools.

This position is a fixed term 12-month appointment, with continuing tenure subject

to satisfactory performance and funding.

Desirable skills:

A PhD in medical science, biotechnology or related field.
Post-graduate laboratory experience in cellular biology techniques including

cloning, cell culture, western blotting, sequencing, immunocytochemistry, flow
cytometry, viral vectors (especially vectors based on adeno associated virus
(AAV)), designing gene therapy constructs for genetic modification of cultured cells
and gene editing technology.

Demonstrated post-graduate experience in animal (mouse/rat) handling.
Ability to conduct research with minimal supervision and demonstrate a level of

independence and teamwork, responsibility and/or management as well as
supervisory skills.

Discretion to innovate within own function and take responsibility for outcomes;

design, develop and test protocols; analyse and report experimental data.

Ability to set priorities and monitor work flows and systems within area of

responsibility.

Excellent communication, database management, computer literacy and analytical

skills with precise laboratory data management.

The successful applicant will be provided with a competitive remuneration package in
accordance with qualifications and experience. Additional benefits include the provision of
a Public Benevolent Institution salary packaging scheme and participation in an employer-
contributed superannuation fund.

Applications should include a cover letter (citing PV2103), curriculum vitae and contact
details (phone/email) of three professional referees and be forwarded to
recruitment@cmri.org.au
Closing date for applications is 29th January 2021.

title: Research Officer, 4 Positions, Molecular Neurobiology Research Group and Translational Vectorology Unit

description:
ElectraNet helps power South Australia and the economy. We own, build and operate the high voltage transmission network that delivers electricity from generators to distributors, enabling retailers to supply power to homes, businesses and communities. As a leading asset and network manager, we are trusted to deliver our customers with affordable and reliable energy solutions.

The Opportunity

The Graduate Environmental Advisor contributes to field environmental management advice and audit services to assist in the planning and management of field activities and to those who undertake field activities.

The Graduate Environmental Advisor monitors environmental management performance by working closely with internal customers and external service providers to ensure compliance with ElectraNet’s environmental management systems, while also evaluating service provider operational compliance with approved environmental management plans.

This role is being offered on a full time, contract basis to 30 June 2022.

About You

You are highly motivated and along with a tertiary qualification in Environmental Science, Environmental Management or Environmental Sustainability, you will have practical experience in a similar environmental position within electricity, construction, manufacturing or similar industry (as a guide approximately 1 year).

You will also have proven skills in environmental compliance assurance across the areas of native vegetation and cultural heritage, plus demonstrated experience in environmental auditing and investigation. Field environmental monitoring techniques including soil sampling, groundwater testing, and the development and management of databases for the capture and interrogation of this data are desirable.

Given the remote nature of our field work, experience in the use of GIS and 4WD experience will be preferred.

About Us

ElectraNet employs talented individuals who work collaboratively in both a physical and virtual environment where people are empowered and accountable for providing safe, reliable and affordable energy and infrastructure solutions.

Safety is at the heart of all that we do, and our most valuable assets are our people. We understand the importance of work/life balance and enable our employees to work flexibly to achieve their outcomes. We provide paid volunteering and paternity/maternity leave as well as additional personal leave. We promote a growth mindset to ensure our people are set up for success now and in the future.

We are mindful of the impact of COVID-19 on our community and environment and will work flexibly with you throughout our recruitment process and during onboarding to ensure your safety and success upon commencement.

We are offering a competitive remuneration package of circa $92,000 inclusive of superannuation plus eligibility for up to 15% performance-based bonus. Applications close Friday 29 January 2021.
title: Graduate Environmental Advisor

description:
Job Reference Number 20-MHDIV-7350
Classification APS Level 5
Job Title Departmental Officers (several positions)
Division Mental Health Division
Branch Various Branches
Section Various Sections
Location Woden, ACT
Status Ongoing
Employment type Full-time
Salary Range $76,009 - $82,200
Security Clearance Baseline (Protected, Highly Protected, Restricted, Confidential)
Desirable Qualifications A university degree in a relevant field, such as health science,

health economics, mental health research, epidemiology or
social work, or relevant work experience would be beneficial
(but not mandatory).

Contact Officer Contact: Melissa Caldow
Ph: 02 6289 4676
Email: Melissa.Caldow@health.gov.au

Contact: Dianne Braggett
Ph: 02 6289 2372
Email: Dianne.Braggett@health.gov.au

Eligibility
To be eligible for employment with the Department of Health applicants must be an

Australian citizen at the time an offer of employment is made.

An applicant’s suitability for employment with Health will also be assessed through a
variety of pre-employment check processes, such as:
Satisfactory completion of an Australian Federal Police criminal history check,

and where relevant a Working with Children and Vulnerable People Check.
Completion of a medical declaration and pre-employment medical (where

required).
Obtaining and maintaining a security clearance, or hold a current security

clearance of an appropriate level.
Providing evidence of qualifications.

Division Responsibilities
The Mental Health Division supports Australians with, or at risk of, mental illness by
improving service integration for a more effective and efficient mental health system. The
Division supports the Prime Minister’s National Suicide Prevention Adviser to develop and
implement the whole-of-government Toward Zero Suicide target. The Division builds
collaborative and productive relationships with stakeholders to design and deliver evidence-
based mental health and suicide prevention services and policies. This includes working
collaboratively with Primary Health Networks to deliver regional services based on assessed
need, as well as state and territory governments to promote integration and coordination of
services at the local level.
The Division prioritises investment in support and services which provide access through
multiple channels, digital and frontline, to ensure people get the right support at the right
time. This includes building the mental health workforce capacity; providing support to
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities; providing support during disasters; and
delivering child and youth services. The Division supports Ministers through the provision of
timely, high quality advice.
The Division continues to build capability through the development of effective systems and
processes to efficiently delivery and manage projects, programs and grants to achieve
deliver the Government’s mental health and suicide prevention agenda.

Branch Responsibilities
The Division comprises three branches:

The Suicide Prevention and Mental Health Policy Branch supports national mental

health reform and policy development, including leading the development of the
Australian Government’s response to the Productivity Commission’s Inquiry into
Mental Health, supporting the Prime Minister’s National Suicide Prevention Adviser,
working with the National Mental Health Commission, and developing a new
national mental health workforce strategy. The Branch also leads a range of related
activities including suicide prevention, digital mental health and veteran’s mental
health.

The Mental Health Supports Branch delivers a range of policies and programs to

ensure people can access the mental health services they need. This includes mental
health services through the Medicare Benefits Schedule, targeted mental health
programs for vulnerable and hard to reach groups, rural and remote mental health
and psychosocial support for people with severe mental illness. The Branch also
provides a Program Management Office function for the Division.

The Mental Health Services and Evidence Branch is the hub of service delivery and

mental health emergency response. The branch has a focus on prevention and early
intervention, development, implementation and evaluation of national initiatives

such as perinatal mental health, child and youth mental health, eating disorders,
adult mental health centres and mental health clinics. The Branch provides support
for the work of the first Deputy Chief Medical Officer for mental health and provides
data and analytics capability, building an evidence base to inform future mental
health reform.

Positions are available in a range of sections in each branch.

Key Responsibilities
Roles may include activities such as:

Assisting with the development, implementation and evaluation of high profile

national mental health policies, programs and projects and related grant
opportunities;

Contributing to policy development and advice on mental health policy issues;
Drafting a range of documents such as policy advice, reports, briefs, minutes and

correspondence, for a broad range of audiences;

Liaising with internal and external stakeholders and managing projects

collaboratively, including with mental health organisations, other government
agencies and expert advisory groups;

Analysis, interpretation and evaluation of information/data from various sources;
Contributing to data, reporting and analytical projects;
Working within a small team to achieve results; and
Making a positive contribution to branch and divisional culture and activities.

Key Capabilities
Key capabilities for these roles are:

Sound knowledge and skills related to research and analysis.
Experience in policy and/or grant/program management, ability to think

strategically, solve problems and analyse information;

Excellent organisation and time management skills, with a proven ability to show

initiative, work independently and take responsibility for progressing tasks and
projects.

High quality written and interpersonal communication skills, including good

attention to detail and ability to tailor reports and briefings to the audience;

Experience building and sustaining positive working relationships within teams, and

with internal and external stakeholders;

Demonstrated initiative, ability to take personal responsibility for work, produce

accurate work in a fast-paced environment, manage competing priorities, and
flexibility to respond to changing priorities; and

Demonstrated commitment to the APS Code of Conduct and Values.

Desirable Experience

Desirable experience varies for each role, and includes relevant work experience or

proficiency in health policy development and implementation, policy and program
evaluation, data analytics, Microsoft Excel or grants/program management.

A university degree in a relevant field, such as health science, health economics,

mental health research, epidemiology or social work, or relevant work experience
would be beneficial (but not mandatory).

Knowledge or understanding, or the ability to quickly acquire an understanding, of

mental health policy, the mental health care sector and Australian Government
procurement and grant opportunity processes would also be highly valued.

For roles in the Mental Health Data and Analysis section, desirable experience

includes interpreting data, synthesising information from a range of sources and
contributing to analysis of key data assets to brief government.

Please Note
Applicants found suitable through this process will be placed in a merit pool which the
Division may use for up to 12 months from the date of advertising.

Application Response
Your application will be assessed on your ability to demonstrate that you possess, or have
the real potential to develop, the required skills, knowledge, experience and qualifications
to perform the role. These requirements are based on the information provided to you as
part of the job advertisement, in line with the APS Work Level Standards.
Applicants are required to provide a statement of claims framed around the key duties and
key capabilities. Your statement of claims should be no more than one page in total with a
font no smaller than size 10. Applications that do not meet these requirements may not
be considered.

Work Environment Description
Responsibilities – As detailed in Section 28 of the Work Health and Safety Act 2011 while at
work, a worker must:

Take reasonable care for his or her own health and safety
Take reasonable care that his or her acts or omissions do not adversely affect the

health and safety of other persons

Comply, so far as the worker is reasonably able, with any reasonable instruction that

is given by the person conducting the business or undertaking to allow the person to
comply with this Act

Cooperate with any reasonable policy or procedure of the person conducting the

business or undertaking relating to health or safety at the workplace that has been
notified to workers

Complete all WHS related induction and training
Report all work related incidents and/or illnesses to the WHS Section

Description Requirement Additional Information

working on a computer is
